messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] submarines in Utah
messages.msgSnippet: I m formerly from N. Idaho, and my husband was born and raised there...and although it is beautiful, can you say LEAD POISONING?  ;)  Not a great place to
messages.messageBody:
I'm formerly from N. Idaho, and my husband was born
and raised there...and although it is beautiful, can
you say LEAD POISONING? ;) Not a great place to
raise kids--at least along the I-90 corridor. Further
north, like Sandpoint, is very nice, and further
south, like Moscow, is also nice, although that's not
called "north" idaho, at least unless you're from
extreme southern idaho! ;)

We lived in Challis for a few years, and it's nice
there, if you don't mind -40 winters. Salt Lake was
out nearest "big city", although it was 6 hours or so
away, and we would go holiday shopping there every
year. If you are looking to get "away from it all",
Challis is perfect (200 miles from a mall!)
Dana
Montana Mama

messages.subject: submarines in Utah
messages.msgSnippet: Hello all, I just joined a few weeks ago and I am soooo glad to have found this group.  I live in Salt Lake City, and have never heard about a submarine
messages.messageBody:
Hello all,

I just joined a few weeks ago and I am soooo glad to have found this group. I live in Salt Lake City, and have never heard about a submarine testing facility here in Utah. I'm going to ask my husband, the geography/geology/history/military coverup expert in our family, and see what we can dig up.

I've been really enjoying the relocation discussions, too. We're looking to leave Utah in the next few years, even though we don't want to go too far--maybe Idaho or Wyoming (the Salt Lake valley is getting too crowded for our taste). If anyone on the list is from northern Idaho or northern Wyoming, I'd love to hear how you like it.

Tawni
